Executive Summary

1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Aqueous Ammonia Storage System. Facility?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.
2.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The primary activity at the facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.
Aqua ammonia (20% of ammonia by weight) is stored in two 10,000 gallon above ground tanks at the site. The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 132,000 pounds. The total quantity of ammonia present in the aqua ammonia, based on 20% active ingredient by weight, is 26,000 pounds. 
3.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Aqueous Ammonia Storage.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  
 
Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the Aqueous Ammonia Storage.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation  
Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the facility and plant personnel to make the worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent anal

ysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an aqueous ammonia release.  The facility utilizes  manual shutoffs, and emergency shutdown systems.
 
4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 2, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of aqueous ammonia. Prevention program 2 elements are listed below:
?    2755.1 Safety Information
?    2755.2 Hazard Review
?    2755.3 Operating Procedures
?    2755.4 Training
?    2755.5 Maintenance
?    2755.6 Compliance Audits
?    2755.7 Incident Information
5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of aqueous ammonia at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.  
6.    EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSIS
Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, ?2745.6(l); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted:  
?    The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  
o    During the June 2009 PHA a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of aqueous ammonia were addressed.  The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact.

d. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.
O    The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.

O    The most recent field verification of equipment was conducted June 2009 and included the major equipment of the process.
Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.6 (l), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of aqueous ammonia were addressed by the Hazard Review.
7.    FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE
The use of flammable materials at the facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 
8.    FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE
The use of flammable materials at the facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
9.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Bear River Supply will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. The facility has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.
An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the req

uirements of the CCR Title 8 ?3220 is in place.
10.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Hazard Review (HR) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the April 17th 2009 HR Report.  Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by December 2009.
